Prerequisites: ACG 2071, CGS 1100 OR CGS 1060 WITH C OR HIGHER
Course Description: THIS COURSE EXAMINES THE CONCEPTS AND TERMINOLOGY OF ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND THE USE OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FOR DECISION MAKING IN ACCOUNTING AND AUDITING.
Objectives / Learning Outcome(s) / Major:
1.  DESIGN BUSINESS PROCESSES AND REPRESENT THEM WITH DOCUMENTATION TOOLS.
2.  IDENTIFY WHAT COMPUTER FRAUD IS AND EXPLAIN HOW INFORMATION SYSTEMS CAN BE ABUSED.
3. APPLY ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS CONCEPTS TO DEVELOP DATA FLOWS AND ACCURATE    DATABASES USEFUL AND NECESSARY FOR STORING AND UTILIZING ACCOUNTING DATA.
4.  DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT WELL-STRUCTURED DATABASES TO ENABLE BUSINESS PROCESSES.
5.  QUERY DATABASES TO LOCATE INFORMATION USEFUL FOR PROVIDING INSIGHTS ABOUT OPERATIONS AND PERFORMANCE.
6.  EVALUATE ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND BUSINESS PROCESSES.
7.  DEMONSTRATE SYSTEMS DEVELOPMENT, DOCUMENTATION AND SYSTEMS ANALYSIS.
8.  IDENTIFY THE NEEDS OF AN AUDITING-BASED INFORMATION SYSTEM.
9.  EVALUATE INTERNAL CONTROLS IN INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND DESIGN CONTROLS TO MITIGATE RISKS.
Textbook(s): ACCOUNTING INFORMATION SYSTEMS, 11E, GELINAS, DULL, WHEELER, & HILL.
Transfer Status: GUARANTEED TRANSFER TO INSTITUTION OFFERING SAME COURSE.
